instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01949: What is 820-01949? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .
definitions.PP0V9_SSD0: What is PP0V9_SSD0? This is a power rail for the soldered on SSD on newer Macbooks. .
definitions.PLT_RST_L: What is PLT_RST_L? This is an abbreviation of “PLT_RESET_L” – when you see “PLT_RST_L", assume the person meant to type PLT_RESET_L.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> brain dead
threads.message:
Hi, I'm working on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board which has slight coffee spill on it. Affected areas are <RESISTOR>R7439</RESISTOR>, some corrosion on caps around 7210 and <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>. <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR>/7101 have been eaten away along with their pads. I have cleaned up all corrosion, replaced components, resoldered <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and recovered traces.

-Board starts, but doesn't show any image on the screen and there is no chime.
-Caps Lock doesn't light up
-When I put it into DFU mode Apple Configurator detects it but can't revive or restore - after some time of waiting "installing software" just dissapears and shows lock with status "booted"
-thermal camera doesn't show anything heating up
-tested with other battery - the same
-the only activity computer has is clikcing trackpad

Some basic measurements:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12,72V
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD0</SIGNAL> - 0,9V
<SIGNAL>PPVCCQ_ANI_SSD0</SIGNAL> - 1,8V
<SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> - 2,5V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_IO_SSD0</SIGNAL> - 1,8V
<SIGNAL>PPVCCIN_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0,601V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> brain dead
threads.message:
With 0.6V on VCORE, machine seems to boot.
It gets stuck for some reason.
You should check the board alone on the desk; just charger and USB tester connected.
Use USB-C hub with PD support; connect charger on it.
<SIGNAL>PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> comes on?

Be aware, <RESISTOR>R7439</RESISTOR> problem could caused an overvoltage and damaged PCH.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> brain dead
threads.message:
Board alone takes 20V and is floating around 0.075A. 

<SIGNAL>PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> is not comming on, it's flat 0V, it doesn't even spike.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> brain dead
threads.message: Do you still get 0.6V on CPU core?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> brain dead
threads.message: No, CPU VCORE now is 0V. As I know this board needs to have good battery connected to boot, right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> brain dead
threads.message:
In most cases, need the battery.
Always better to test, to avoid any doubt.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> brain dead
threads.message: I already have tested it with another battery, the same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> brain dead
threads.message: Still no CPU core, when trigger <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, with both charger and battery?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> brain dead
threads.message:
With battery and charger there is VCORE. There is no VCORE when I connect just charger to board alone on the bench.

EDIT: Actually now I don't get VCORE. Battery and charger connected, board in topcase with everything connectes as before..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> brain dead
threads.message:
Check only with charger and battery connected.
You may need to trigger <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> brain dead
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> brain dead
threads.message: Did you trigger <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> first, still no reaction?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> brain dead
threads.message: Yes, I trigger it and anyway VCORE doesn’t show up anymore, though I haven’t done anything to the board..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> brain dead
threads.message:
Corrosion around CPU power supply is very bad.
CPU may be damaged now.
You can try to heat it with quality flux; in case of accumulated crap underneath.

Check all resistors, caps and traces related with CPU power supply.
